subject: Research Update: YS Index of Female Expatriation
body:
YS Index of Female Expatriation
  
 
  
Image of 'Expat' (miniseries) promotional still from Amazon Prime. (
source
) 
Hi Dear YS members. 
I would like to share the ‘Our Index of the Female Expatriation’ as my last Young SIETAR Research Project. I began our YS research project ‘How to Make Intercultural Connections with Female Expatriates: Exploring the Invisible Way of Successful Global Relocation’ in 2023. 
However, it couldn’t gain speed because of progress limitations as voluntary research. In the meantime, I need to step down from the YS research coordinator position for personal reasons. I believe that creating narratives about female expatriation has positive social impacts across cultures. So, I would like to share ‘Our Index of the Female Expatriation’ as my last work paper. 
How do I figure this out?
 
Here is our starting point. I could be creative in my research when I enjoy art such as paintings, books, music, film, etc. Along the same lines, I encountered some points that I would like to research in the miniseries ‘
Expats (Amazon Prime Series
)’ 
Summary
 (Research Keywords in 
Purple
)
The miniseries is summarised through the point of view of expatriation. Six episodes talk about Hong Kong residents who come from other countries. The miniseries largely centers around Margaret who is living in Hong Kong as an 
expatriate partner
. However, it also depicts 
a multifaceted group of female expatriates
. 
In the first half of the series, we come to know the background of ‘Margaret' (Nicole Kidman) and her family. She had given up her job to follow her loving husband ‘Clarke’ to Hong Kong. 
Their physical environment is good, living in a prestigious apartment block with other rich expats
. However, Margaret felt 
negative feelings
 such as isolation and anxiety
 because of 
her career break
 compared with her friends who are successful as CEOs or artists in her home country and, adding to this, conflict with her husband regarding his extension of expatriation time. 
In the middle of the series, the main issue happened. 'Gus', her youngest child  (among three) went 
missing
 in the middle of the market while she hung out with Mercy, a woman who wanted a nanny job. Later, while Margaret and her husband don’t give up on finding their son, other drama unfolds involving Hilary, who is a 
neighbor of Margaret’s family
. Through the scenes of Hilary's mother visiting Hong Kong to see her
, the audience can indirectly feel how she is 
tired of stereotypes as an Indian female and Indian expatriate
.
Index
| The Cultural Adaptation of Expatriates |
Andersen, N. (2021). Mapping the expatriate literature: A bibliometric review of the field from 1998 to 2017 and identification of current research fronts. The International Journal of Human Resource Management, 32(22), 4687-4724.
Davies, S., Kraeh, A., & Froese, F. (2015). Burden or support? The influence of partner nationality on expatriate cross-cultural adjustment.Journal of Global Mobility,3(2), 169-182.
Kierner, A. (2018). Expatriated dual-career partners: hope and disillusionment.Journal of Global Mobility: The Home of Expatriate Management Research,6(3/4), 244-257.
| Relationship Management: Neighborhood of Margaret’s family |
van Bakel, M. (2024).Breaking out of the Expat Bubble: How to Make Intercultural Connections and Friends. Taylor & Francis.
van Bakel, M. (2012). In touch with the Dutch: A longitudinal study of the impact of a local host on the success of the expatriate assignment.
| Multifaceted Female Expatriates |
Dayal, D., & Chauhan, R. K. (2024). CONTEMPORARY INDIAN WOMEN ARTISTS AS DIGITAL SOCIAL COMMENTATORS ON WOMEN'S EMPOWERMENT.
Fleury, A. (2016). Understanding women and migration: A literature review. Washington, DC, 55.
Bastida, M. (2018). Yes, they can do it! Exploring female expatriates’ effectiveness. European Research on Management and Business Economics,24(2), 114-120.
Larkin, R., & Woodcock Ross, J. (2024). Unaccompanied migrant girls: navigating religious girlhood in the UK. Ethnic and Racial Studies, 1-21.
Lee, T. (2023). Migration Data and Marriage Migrants in the Republic of Korea. 
If you know any additional helpful materials related to this topic, please contact 
research@youngsietar.org
 before June 30th for it to be shared with other members. After this date the information will likely be posted as a blog and / or under our Members Only 'Research' information area.  
– Ji-yu Bak (B)
  
 
 
 
YS Website 
  
  
This message was sent to you by 
Young Sietar
 
If you no longer wish to receive these emails, you can 
unsubscribe
 at any time 
111 Front Street West, Suite 111, Toronto, Ontario M0 0L0 Canada 
1-111-111-1111, 
https://www.youngsietar.org/

subject: RE: ATTENTION  Sarah & Vince/  what I have done for FINAL DECK Alpharetta Hispanic Spotlights
body:
Hello team 
😉
 
First of all, SN, I hope you see this after your PTO. This is just for documentation purposes.
 
Based on email sent by HOLLINA, here are steps taken vs pending. 
Vince, I marked area where you will assist. ( looking forward to our meeting at 2pm today)
 
FINAL DECK ALPHARETTA HISPANIC /LATINO
P Coleman June 18-20,2024
 
WORK SCHEDULE REPORT ON DECK FOR ALPHARETTA HISPANIC /LATINO:
As discussed between Hollina and Sarah,  this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. 
 
To recap the changes that  BSC ALPH would like to see regarding timing and the other items talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes 
DONE!  We will make sure facilitator is aware of tips given in previously delivered “RACE MATTERS” session 
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking  
DONE!  
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive. 
PC added to notes: 
ATTENTION FACILITATOR: Action plan geared to engage participants as much as possible for a "productive" 
outcome
. 
Think
 SMART goals Specific-Measurable-Attainable-Reaslistic-Time-bound. MAKE IT COUNT
! 
​
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us: 
PC: We have sent dates Ricardo is available and waiting for BSC to get back to us.  He is
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
RICARDO IS AVAILABLE JULY 1,2,3,8 & 9   
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session.  
PC: We are planning his travel accordingly.
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this. 
PC: YES! We had spoken about 75mn sessions for that reason. 
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees 
VINCE, can you please coordinate?
Patricia M Coleman

Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung
Principal DE&I Consultant
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
She / Her / Hers
Chicago, IL 
hollina.ung@bsci.com
www.bostonscientific.com

CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?

Sarah

Subject:
 Regionalization Work for Canada
Importance:
 High
 
Hi Jas! Patricia gave me your email, I am reaching out about some urgent customization work that needs to be done by the end of next week. I have included some background below and attached. 
We are closed tomorrow for Juneteenth and I am traveling Thurs-Fri this week, but Vince and Chuck can help coordinate your involvement, should you choose to jump in
. It’s probably about 5-10 hours of work to do this customization.
 
Here is a link to the folder of materials: 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/4gj3w0n4y51fktmw8jpq0/AB47h9oHGfeLnA9yslfDPOA?rlkey=fmnik2n22nbowbfj6cjjzu5xy&st=su66k6cc&dl=0
 
BACKGROUND: The job entails building some slides to tailor the attached training for the Canada region (see PDF). It’s for Boston Scientific, a global medical devices company that is one of our biggest clients. 
 
This training is called “Leading Inclusively: What You Need To Know About Your Black Talent,” and it is part of a multi-year, corporate-wide anti-racism program called “ARCH” (stands for “Anti-Racism and Cultural History”). I can give you more details about the program if you decide to do the work, but for now you can check out 
this link
 on BSC’s website, and suffice to say that this Leading Inclusively course is for roughly 5,000 people managers across the BSC globe. We have already delivered it to hundreds of managers in the US and EMEA regions. Now, we are expanding to the other regions. The idea is to tailor the content by region, so participants in don’t feel like the training is too US-focused.
 
To tailor for Canada, we did focus groups with BSC’s LATAM stakeholders (notes are in the linked folder), and created recommendations for tailoring the training already (also in the linked folder).
 Your job would be to implement these recommendations by doing research and creating the DRAFT slides
. We would do the formatting of course. Vince and I would work with you to make sure you understand the detailed learning objectives of what we were tailoring, and check in with you along the way to ensure it goes smoothly.
 
You will see from reading the regionalization recommendations that there is a core question we are grappling with when doing these regional tailorings, and that is: “is it appropriate to focus on the US Black Experience?”
 
The answer is yes, AND….
 
Yes, we want to focus on the US Black Experience because BSC is an American company, based in the US, and colleagues around the globe need to understand the particular experience of their US colleagues.  AND – we want to make sure that we are ALSO talking about race and racism in a way that is relevant to folks in different regions. Some regions have pushed back pretty strongly on the idea of doing training focused on race or Blackness at all (APAC, for example). 
 
We need this work completed by next Wednesday so that we can review it in time for a meeting with the client on July 1, would that be possible for you? If you have questions, please reply to this email and Vince or I will respond!
 
Thanks for letting us know!
 
Sarah
 
 
Sarah Nodarse
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW
4753 N Broadway, Flr. 2
Chicago, IL 60640

773-474-9138 (direct)

Valuing Diversity for Innovation: Culture, Race and Difference in Our BSC Workplaces
 
Front page welcome images and paragraph
 
LESSON 1: Introduction: 
Camile Chang Gilmore video
Learning objectives
Mike Mahoney’s quote about valuing diversity
 
LESSON 2: Understanding Diversity: The Power of Culture
Introductory paragraph
Defining culture, race, and ethnicity
Unpacking definition of culture (values/behaviors, learned/shared, community)
Cultural iceberg
Dimensions of Diversity (Cultural Groups/Diversity Wheel)
Our identity is the collection of cultural communities that define who we are and how we see ourselves
Interactivity: Influence us at different levels at different times, How we see ourselves can be different than how others see us
Activity: top 3 groups you see yourself, top 3 others connect with you
·
         
Org culture vs. individual culture graphic 
Explain that BSC has a culture and many subcultures 
Distinguish org culture from individual culture
·
         
Interpreting cultural differences
Seeing behavior via our own lenses
Importance of putting on other lenses to understand and leverage diversity
 
LESSON 3: Race as an Influential Cultural Group 
Defining Racism, Colorblindness, Intersectionality
4 types of racism (internalized, interpersonal, institutional, structural)
Includes global examples
Expand the box: Learn more about the myths of race
True or false – knowledge testing flip cards
An Unbroken Thread of History
European Colonialism
The Transatlantic Trade of Enslaved African People
Impact of History on Anti-Blackness & Racism (includes global examples)
Expand the box: Learn more about racialization
Real stories of Global anti-Blackness 
Includes 2 global stories
The history and impact of colorism
Self Reflection Activity
Color Blind vs. Color Brave
Combating racism in the workplace (stereotypes, stereotype threat, microaggressions)
 
LESSON 4: Living our BSC Values
Intercultural competence
The Platinum Rule
The DIN model with scenario practice
Effective questions to ask when interpreting from the other person’s perspective
 
LESSON 5: Wrap-up
What we’ve learned in this course
None of what we’ve learned means anything if we don’t take action. Here are just a few suggestions for valuing diversity and practicing inclusion to advance innovation and collaboration at Boston Scientific (5 listed out)
Closing statement

 (MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

We’re introducing new terms on the use of Miro AI features
On July 17, 2024, we’re introducing a new 
AI Features Addendum
 that will supplement the agreement you have with Miro. We’re also updating the 
Miro Privacy Policy 
. These changes make it easier for you to understand what to expect from Miro as you use our AI features, such as Miro Assist.
You can review the new terms 
here
. At a glance, these updates explain:
•
How Miro uses inputs you provide and output generated by Miro AI features.
•
Ownership of output generated by Miro’s AI features.
•
Limitations associated with the quickly-evolving technologies that underpin Miro AI features.
You don't have to do anything to accept these changes. By continuing to use Miro after July 17th you are agreeing to the new terms. If you have questions check the FAQ below.
AI Features Addendum FAQ
We don’t train generative AI with your board content.
 Miro relies on commercially available models (such as developed by OpenAI) as well as open-source models that are trained with licensed data and public domain content where copyright has expired. Miro may use usage data and other meta data to improve your product experience and develop features like diagramming and sticky clustering.
You can choose not to participate in our AI feature improvement efforts.
 We currently don’t use your input into and output from Miro AI features to improve our product. If we intend to change our training approach, we will inform you upfront.
You own your board content.
 No license granted to Miro to operate its services will supersede your ownership rights.
Thank you for using Miro! 
The Miro Team
You have received this mandatory email service announcement to update you about important changes in connection with Miro’s Terms of Service. You are a subject to Miro's Terms of Service because you have an account with Miro. 
Please do not reply to this email, as we are unable to respond from this email address. If you need support, please visit 
Miro’s Help Center
.
 
This email was sent to 
v.bongiovanni@lcwmail.com
. 
 
Miro, 201 Spear St., Suite 1100
San Francisco, CA 94105, United States
 
Help Center
  |  
Privacy Policy

Subject:
 RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
 
Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung
Principal DE&I Consultant
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
She / Her / Hers
Chicago, IL 
hollina.ung@bsci.com
www.bostonscientific.com

Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

subject: RE: For Discussion / Slide Deck
body:
Brian –Great talking with you today! Thank you for the fantastic work. I like the direction everything is taking.
 
A recap of next steps:
-Brian will finalize the last bits of research
-Vince will review the U.S and EMEA decks to give Brian an estimate of how much material we need (e.g. 10 minutes vs 30 minutes or another amount)
-Vince will set up a meeting with all of us and Eileen for Mon 6-24
 
Did I forget anything??
 
Talk to you Monday!!
 
Thanks for everything,
Sarah

I'd like to check in on these items when we review the slides, and of course any other items.  I'm having issues sending you the slides as they seem to have heavy embedded features.  Will walk you through those online and then send.  
 
Items to discuss
Political tensions and dynamics eg gender expression / elections etc

LGBTQ+
Videos / timing and selections
Time and slide count
Glossary
Quiz
Text for slides / Data for slides
Anything else you'd like to discuss
 
Look forward to talking more soon.
 
Brian

Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,

Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

this article
 in the Chicago History Museum Magazine for a native perspective on land acknowledgements and the City of Chicago.

Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung
Principal DE&I Consultant
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
She / Her / Hers
Chicago, IL 
hollina.ung@bsci.com
www.bostonscientific.com

Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung
Principal DE&I Consultant
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
She / Her / Hers
Chicago, IL 
hollina.ung@bsci.com
www.bostonscientific.com

: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

subject: Urgent tasks - this coming week / BSC Update
body:
Hi Vince, as per our meeting today, I’m recapping the tasks I delegated to you and copying in Chuck just so he is also in the loop for how things are moving forward, especially and most critically on the BSC pieces.
 
Boston Scientific Regional Leading Inclusively Delivery Plan – 
Brian and Adriana already gave verbal agreement to do the facilitation, we will ask Latoya when we meet with her today
 
Vince to look in Compass/SOW to confirm # of sessions per region (5 APAC, 1 of which is AUS-NZ, 5 LATAM, and 1 for Canada)
Vince to email Brian, Adriana & Latoya to confirm availability for facilitation and get tentative dates
GOAL – have solid info to share with client Wed 6-26 during our meeting
 
Boston Scientific Regional Leading Inclusively Design – 
Vince to schedule a meeting with Eileen, Brian, me, Vince on Monday 6-24 (Brian traveling before), so we can get Eileen’s input on Brian’s content
We are meeting with Latoya at 2 pm – there will be to-dos after this
We are meeting with Adriana and Eileen today at 4 pm – there will be to-dos after that
Vince to coordinate tasks next week to get these drafts final (e.g., set up meetings when needed, respond to SMEs with project related info)
Vince to complete any final tasks 6-27 and 6-28 when I am out of the office 
GOAL – have compelling first drafts of 3 decks (APAC, LATAM, Canada) for the meeting on July 1
 
Boston Scientific Maple Grove SLT SCI Deck
We are talking with Latoya today about the facilitation, once we get her input…
Vince to update slides 17-20, condense into one slide with key, simple, actionable bullets
Vince to build out notes for activities based on input from Latoya 
GOAL – finalize by Wed 6-26
 (I’m out 6-27 & 6-28), send PDF to Hollina & Ken in preparation for meeting on July 1
Deck location:
 
 
GroupM Leading With Inclusion Deck
 – next draft due 6-26 at regular weekly meeting, RP is working on, RP will hand off to Sarah end of this week, Sarah will finalize 6-24 & 6-25. In the meantime:
Vince to revise timeline found here
, focusing on 2 workstreams only (Inclusion for All, Career Advocates) – please have a draft by 6-25 so I can review before the meeting 
😊
Lukeisha specifically requested: NOT to skip August as she had originally requested, to get started right away, as soon as we can finalize content (so, let’s aim for July); to start the Career Advocates program immediately (and she did NOT like the content Ada designed last time, so a hefty design time needs to be built in)
 
 
 
 
That’s it!
 
WHEW!
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Brian

subject: For Viewing and Discussion:  Vice Asia - Being Black and Mixed-Race in China (15 minutes)
body:
Hi Sarah and Vince
I'd like to talk a bit about some parts of this that might be suitable for a clip to be used.  Heads up, some parts are tough viewing and make me cringe because they talk about tough experiences and issues.  These I'd not wish to include.  However, other parts that are more suitable for a general audience are likely to be valuable. I'd like to solicit your input since you know BSC best.
Could you take time to view it before we meet, paying special attention to the following times?  Please see the link below – I would only wish to use components with English subtitles for a regional audience so people who speak Putonghua from China, Singapore, Malaysia etc can follow but others who don't can read the subtitles.  Some of the components are also too politically sensitive for use in China, so I'm thinking of only using key clips.  However, it touches on racism / ethnic identity / colorism etc and the fact that it's in China will lend power to some of the messages, whether Eden's or Audrey's.
2.23-3.24:  Hair touching and boundaries / racism towards Blacks
6.17-6.40:  Racist advertisement - likely too much as for some viewers would perpetuate stereotypes / is too much though real
7.00-7.40:  Likely skip this – too much framing of dating relationships / risk of added stereotyping
8.04-9.30 and about 10.33-12.09:  Contrasts in mixed-race experience and colorism - Audrey's experience
13.29-14.54:  Insights into general stereotyping and differences in mixed-race experience - Eden's experience in closing
I look forward to talking later this morning.
Brian
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uIoKuMVhLdM
Being Black And Mixed-Race in China | Gen 跟 China
Being mixed-race is often considered a privilege in China, yet Blackness can be stigmatised. Mixed-race Eurasian face filters and models are prolific on Chinese social media, but the same preference isn’t given to mixed-race Black and Chinese people, even though they are a growing demographic. In fact, there is a small pocket of Chinese ...
www.youtube.com

subject: Checking in / Question on Elearning content focus
body:
Hi Sarah and Vince
I'd like to check in briefly on a couple questions as I edit the slides before sending over to you so you get them by the end of today your time.
Could you please confirm whether ARCH participants are doing the e-learning that I reviewed and gave comments on a couple years ago for BSC?  I believe that in the past BSC may have had the concept of doing prelearning before the ARCH session.
I'm just checking how much alignment I need in terms of the new slides and what you had in the earlier e-learning content.  I'd like to doublecheck that I avoid any overlap on input for specific areas.
Brian

Sarah,
 
Thank you for inviting Alisa to our bi-weekly ARCH meeting and thank you Alisa for attending. 
 
Recapping our expectations of next steps:
LCW to provide new delivery date for the eLearning by noon on 6/14.
LCW to provide region-specific facilitator availability in September/October for LATAM, APAC and Canada on next bi-weekly call scheduled for 6/26.
LCW to provide first draft customized power point decks for LATAM, APAC and Canada on the call scheduled for 6/27.
 
Other notes: 
LCW confirmed translation costs are included in customization fees and turnaround time for translation is 2 weeks once customizations are final.
Rebecca (Director of Business Development) has been assigned to work on global roll out full time.
Meeting has been scheduled with Camille, Shani, Chuck and Alisa to discuss recent events.
 
Thank you for understanding our concerns in this recent discussion. 
 
Bethany

subject: Scoro version update planned
body:
Hi Vince, Your Scoro site lcw.scoro.com will be updated to a new version on 2024-06-18 at 05:30 am America/Chicago. You don’t need to take any ...
 
 
 
Log in → 
Hi Vince,
Your Scoro site 
lcw.scoro.com
 will be updated to a new version on 2024-06-18 at 05:30 am America/Chicago.
You don’t need to take any action regarding this update. As a cloud platform, we at Scoro do that for you! But we ask you not to schedule any important activities in Scoro for that time.
Here's the full list of new features and improvements.
Have a nice day!
Team Scoro

Sarah,

LCW to provide new delivery date for the eLearning by noon on 6/14.

Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence

Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence

-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?

Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung

Diversity, Equity and Inclusion

Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

CAUTION

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations.

Subject:

Hi Patricia,
 
Boston Scientific does not have access to dropbox. Sarah should be able to add it to our SP. I’d like to see these changes made before presenting this to the Alpharetta leadership team:
Slide 4 has extra spaces in the sentence about using laptop for notes – before laptop, at the beginning of the sentence and after laptop
Missing a comma after, learn – for listen to learn, not judge
Slide 8 refers to Latinx – we need to consistently use Hispanic/Latino across the presentation
Slide 11 – for the purposes of the audience and to use more straightforward and plain language, further simplifying the first bullet point to “Recognize that it is best practice for work-related interactions to be conducted in English”
Slide 13 is the wrong slide. This was supposed to be an interactive activity where we ask participants to reflect on one of the questions on the screen and provide a response on how they will answer the questions listed. 
Slide 16 has an extra space in the first statement between colleagues and may.
Need to have periods after all the sentences for consistency.
 
@Vince Bongiovanni
 to your question in the separate chain – we will share information on timing of the sessions once the deck is approved and signed off after review with the Alpharetta leadership team.
 
Kind regards,

subject: LCW Missed Interview/Reschedule
body:
Hi Emily,
I have just been informed that you scheduled your interview but nobody showed up. I am very sorry about that; the interview never appeared on Sarah's calendar like it should have. We think Calendly may have glitched.
We would love to be able to reschedule with you. I am free next Monday after 1pm CT or anytime on Tuesday. Let me know if any of those windows work for you. 
Thank you so much, and again my sincerest apologies.
Best,
Vince

subject: June Newsletter
body:
You don't often get email from communication@youngsietar.org. 
Learn why this is important
View this email in your browser
Hello !
We’re looking for new board members
Do you have a desire to get involved and/or shape the future of Young SIETAR? 
Have you ever felt the desire to get involved but don’t know where to start?
Are you interested in interculturalism but would like to learn more? 
Are you a seasoned veteran who is young-at-heart and would like to help mentor newbies and shape the fire? 
Well…
We are currently recruiting to fill the following volunteer positions: 
President 
Secretary
Education Coordinator
Research Coordinator
So, what would you do in these positions? 
President: 
Are you the new face of Young SIETAR?
Every organisation needs a leader – Young SIETAR is no different. We are looking for someone to take on the challenge of representing Young SIETAR to the world beyond as well as guiding our organisation into 2024 and beyond.
Are you the enthusiastic Young SIETARian we are looking for? A heart for Young SIETAR is more important than a track list of experience. Young SIETAR provides a platform to learn for us all – also for its President.
Chairing the meetings of the Young SIETAR Board (about every 6 weeks) and of the General Assembly (once a year), 
facilitates the Board mailing list (depending on activity level)
Represent YS in formal settings and on member level (continuously though with peaks and lows)
Maintain contact and communication with the partners of YS (Sietar network, NGOs etc.) 
Time commitment 10-30 hours a month
Secretary: 
Do you treasure Young SIETAR?
Secretaries are SO important for keeping an organisation afloat. Are you one of those more structured people who like to keep track of things and are not too adverse to numbers? This position might not be seen as the most exciting position, yet it is (and good for your CV) to be working in a virtual team with fellow Young SIETARians from around the globe. From record-keeping, compliance, keeping meeting notes advising others and more! It also offers the opportunity to participate in other projects that are run within YS –  take your pick!
Time commitment 10 - 20 hours a month
 
Education Coordinator: 
Tasks and responsibilities:
Leading and moderating the Training team, which includes organizing meetings, documenting, archiving,etc.
Coordinating, implementing and maintaining of training team projects such as the TOIT 3 and
Webinar projects
Updating and maintaining information related to Training on the YoungSIETAR website
Initiating, supporting and developing new projects and other activities related to Training (such as
Blended Learning, E-learning and intercultural short films).
Working together with the other Content Board members (Research and Education) in coordinating overlapping projects.
Participating in the running of the organisation by providing feedback on and contributing to general board issues (e.g. strategy, improvements of the organisation, etc.)
Initiating, supporting and developing new projects and other activities related to Training (such as YS Cafes and Virtual YS Cafes, Training Library Materials etc.).
Participating in the running of the organisation by providing feedback on and contributing to general board issues (e.g. strategy, improvements of the organisation, etc.)
Note: New activities and initiatives can always be taken up
Time commitment: 8-16 per month (but could be more in periods just before YS Training events)
Research Coordinator: 
Are you the next Research Coordinator?
All you need is an interest in intercultural research; our vision for Research has been about supporting the beginning researcher and bringing research and practice closer together, not necessarily about doing research itself. You can help develop the R in Young SIETAR and contribute to this aspect of the YS community.
Leads the Research team
Initiates and/or supports new events/workshops/ideas for projects related to research & education
Searches for news in the field / Monitor educational and research activities
The YS Research Coordinator will drive the momentum of research-related projects to help create and define a space for members to share and contribute to the intercultural knowledge framework using virtual tools. 
The YS Coordinator is essentially responsible for providing intercultural research content and opportunities for members of Young SIETAR. 
This may involve creating and hosting YS Webinars and YS Virtual Cafes focusing on intercultural research. 
There is also the possibility to contribute to the developing YS mentor program to connect established interculturalists to those who are new to the field. 
Time commitment: 2 + hours per month minimum (varies per project interest) 
If any of these positions sound interesting to you, send your CV and a letter of interest via  today!!

subject: RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
body:
Hi Sarah,
 
As discussed during our call earlier today, this deck is approved to be translated into Spanish. To recap the changes that we would like to see regarding timing and the other items that we talked about:
Slide 14 should be shortened to 2-3 minutes rather than the 8 outlined in speaker notes
Slide 18 should be lengthened to pick up the 5 minutes from slide 14
, to 8 minutes total so that we hear more people share what actions they are gong to be taking 
Call out on not going down the rabbit hole on slide 12 with the role-play – will lean heavily on Ricardo to keep the conversation productive
We would like a call set up with Ricardo for him to meet the Alpharetta leadership team and to review expectations.
 Here are a few times that will work for us:
June 24 at 12:00 or 12:30 PM CT
June 25 at 12:30 PM CT
June 26 at 12:00 or12:30 PM CT
July 10 at 1 or 1:30 PM CT
Aisha will be providing the session times by the end of next week, but please plan for the first session to start at around 8:00 AM ET and the last session to end around 4:30/5:00 PM ET on Wednesday. We recommend that Ricardo fly in the night before for the first session. 
Couple of reminders:
Since the bulk of the participants are DL employees, they may be late to the session, so to ensure that we are not rushing through content, we are allowing for 
a 15 minute buffer 
after each session so that we can cover all the important points with as many people as possible. Aisha will schedule accordingly for this.
LCW will provide the “Intent vs. Impact” slide as a handout for all participants – 240 copies for the 240 participants/attendees
 
Glad to see the progress that we are making on this Spotlight on the Hispanic/Latino Community session. Thank you for your partnership to get us to this point. 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung
Principal DE&I Consultant
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
She / Her / Hers
Chicago, IL 
hollina.ung@bsci.com
www.bostonscientific.com

Importance:

CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

Slide 4 has extra spaces in the sentence about using laptop for notes – before laptop, at the beginning of the sentence and after laptop

Slide 8 refers to Latinx – we need to consistently use Hispanic/Latino across the presentation

Need to have periods after all the sentences for consistency.

: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

subject: Re: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
body:
Hi Sarah,
I was sharing that feedback since you stated in your last email to let you know if I see anything in the speaker notes that need to be addressed. As you may have noticed from past calls with the Alpharetta leadership team, they are very detail-oriented and if we’re not catching these details, they will be, so I would like us to get in front of it. 
Kind regards,
Hollina Ung 
Principal DE&I Consultant

I appreciate this attention to detail. As I stated in my previous email, the speaker notes will still undergo a final round of tweaking when the facilitator does his preparation. 
 
Nonetheless, I have gone ahead and addressed each of your comments in a new version that I have uploaded to Sharepoint (same document name). Please let us know if we can consider the deck final for translation. 
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Hi Sarah,
 
Looking through the speaker notes:
Slide 3: Aisha has shared that the term “ground rules” doesn’t resonate with the group and would recommend using “reminders” instead
Slide 12 notes need to be updated to reflect names and the updated dialogue, taking out the language that the leadership team found comnbativ
Slide 14 says that it’s supposed to be 8 minutes, but then it says “If time - turn to the person you said hello to at the beginning and do the exercise.” Is that because you are prioritizing the activities happening after? 8 minutes seems like a long time for that slide if it’s optional.
Slide 16’s notes seem off because it is asking for feedback, but we still have the Intent vs. Impact activity
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung
Principal DE&I Consultant
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
She / Her / Hers

www.bostonscientific.com

 High
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Bethany and I discussed slide 13 and would like that the slide be presented in the format that we had originally asked for. The initial change request from Aisha was that we make the language more accessible by not using words like mitigate—which I supplied some alternative language that is more accessible. So the request was not to change the questions to statements. The current format is wordy and does not present as well as it did in the question format, which was more visually appealing. 
 
Also, this format now has markers of comments on it, can you remove them? I have one example below – I see them on other slides as well. Also there is a slide listed as a poll, when we have no planned polls for the session – can you remove that?

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

Hi Patricia,
 
Boston Scientific does not have access to dropbox. Sarah should be able to add it to our SP. I’d like to see these changes made before presenting this to the Alpharetta leadership team:
Slide 4 has extra spaces in the sentence about using laptop for notes – before laptop, at the beginning of the sentence and after laptop
Missing a comma after, learn – for listen to learn, not judge
Slide 8 refers to Latinx – we need to consistently use Hispanic/Latino across the presentation
Slide 11 – for the purposes of the audience and to use more straightforward and plain language, further simplifying the first bullet point to “Recognize that it is best practice for work-related interactions to be conducted in English”
Slide 13 is the wrong slide. This was supposed to be an interactive activity where we ask participants to reflect on one of the questions on the screen and provide a response on how they will answer the questions listed. 
Slide 16 has an extra space in the first statement between colleagues and may.
Need to have periods after all the sentences for consistency.
 
@Vince Bongiovanni
 to your question in the separate chain – we will share information on timing of the sessions once the deck is approved and signed off after review with the Alpharetta leadership team.
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung

Looking through the speaker notes:
Slide 3: Aisha has shared that the term “ground rules” doesn’t resonate with the group and would recommend using “reminders” instead
Slide 12 notes need to be updated to reflect names and the updated dialogue, taking out the language that the leadership team found comnbativ
Slide 14 says that it’s supposed to be 8 minutes, but then it says “If time - turn to the person you said hello to at the beginning and do the exercise.” Is that because you are prioritizing the activities happening after? 8 minutes seems like a long time for that slide if it’s optional.

: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah
