Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?

Sarah

subject: notes from groupM meeting 6/7
body:
Hi Sarah,
Here's my notes from the meeting. Lmk if you need clarity on any of them.
It feels a lot disjointed
Missed how we got to sterotype threat
Like the first exercise - but talking points thrw her off
 
Is it inclusive vs misleading
 
Its good pieces but separated
What are we trying to get from this
 
Message around if were all the same would we be able to reach our goals may dirve convo too much towards productivity - move part about goals and change to promote a culture of inclusion
Is it too soon for this point?
Maybe save for the end
 we have diverse talent in the org but they don’t feel they can be themselves, that’s the point to drive home
 
All in survey - areas that decreased in terms of index numbers from 2022 were I feel like I can be my authentic self, and I fear of discrimintation in the company
This is what we heard and these are the things we are trying to protect against
 
Jump between slide 4 and 10, everything inbetween takes a long road to get their that’s linking identity to productivity to culture to etc….too long to get to point
 
Elminate slides 5-7 so you go from 4 to 8
Take out case for inclusion theory
Reformat the slides to tell, heres how I introduce myself, why, because of jarhari window, what is it called to not share, because of code switching
 
Slide 11, change question to what could make you feel like you belong at work
Should the slide connect back to the first couple slides…what would it look like at work to make you feel like you belong?
 
 
 
Call out that this is not a check the box exercise - slide 5 - its not about goals or producitivity, its about everybody feeling comfortable at this org being who they are - were not doing this to prove that diversity matters or build that case, we know that diversity matters
 
Slide 7 is too technical
Would like to speak to ppl as humans beings and want them to channel that during the training
No theory or data point but something like a quote
Need someone to be vulnerable, either through a video or anecdote, etc.
 
 
 
Data - I feel like I really belong at my agency/company (-7)
Data - I can be my authentic self at work, without fear of discrimination (-2)
Best,
Vince
Vince Bongiovanni
(he/him)
Project Assistant
LCW

Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins

-What seems difficult?

 High

: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:

-What seems difficult?

Subject:
 RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
Importance:
 High
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

subject: RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
body:
Hi team,
 
Just checking in on this, I am pasting below the two options we had for simplified language for slide 13 – these are in the 4.12 Sharepoint deck, the one I downloaded to make the final version for signoff.
 
Hollina, can you confirm that Option 2 was the one you proposed? If so I’d like to gently push back…
 
We also discussed as a team, and we prefer Option 1 as it more closely reflects what we teach. I see a few things I would change in Option 2 – in “Understand” there is the term “cultural environment” and then “cultural community” and those two terms used together like that might be confusing. In “Accept” I would not use the term “biased” as it is very negatively connotated and I would predict folks would raise their hands and say “I’m not biased!”. For “Adapt” we thought that the language in Option 1 was simpler.
 
Overall, we recommend using Option 1. In addition, reading them over again, side by side, I would also recommend that we add in “Understand”, for the second bullet, after “shaped my own identity,” “based on the communities I have been a part of.”  
 
 
 
 
 
Eager to hear your thoughts on this so we can get this content locked down! Thank you for your collaboration.
 
Best,
Sarah

Hi Sarah,
 
Bethany and I discussed slide 13 and would like that the slide be presented in the format that we had originally asked for. The initial change request from Aisha was that we make the language more accessible by not using words like mitigate—which I supplied some alternative language that is more accessible. So the request was not to change the questions to statements. The current format is wordy and does not present as well as it did in the question format, which was more visually appealing. 
 
Also, this format now has markers of comments on it, can you remove them? I have one example below – I see them on other slides as well. Also there is a slide listed as a poll, when we have no planned polls for the session – can you remove that?
 
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung

She / Her / Hers
Chicago, IL

www.bostonscientific.com

 RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

Hi Patricia,
 
Boston Scientific does not have access to dropbox. Sarah should be able to add it to our SP. I’d like to see these changes made before presenting this to the Alpharetta leadership team:
Slide 4 has extra spaces in the sentence about using laptop for notes – before laptop, at the beginning of the sentence and after laptop
Missing a comma after, learn – for listen to learn, not judge
Slide 8 refers to Latinx – we need to consistently use Hispanic/Latino across the presentation
Slide 11 – for the purposes of the audience and to use more straightforward and plain language, further simplifying the first bullet point to “Recognize that it is best practice for work-related interactions to be conducted in English”
Slide 13 is the wrong slide. This was supposed to be an interactive activity where we ask participants to reflect on one of the questions on the screen and provide a response on how they will answer the questions listed. 
Slide 16 has an extra space in the first statement between colleagues and may.
Need to have periods after all the sentences for consistency.
 
@Vince Bongiovanni
 to your question in the separate chain – we will share information on timing of the sessions once the deck is approved and signed off after review with the Alpharetta leadership team.
 
Kind regards,
 
Hollina Ung

Hi Sarah,
 
Bethany and I discussed slide 13 and would like that the slide be presented in the format that we had originally asked for. The initial change request from Aisha was that we make the language more accessible by not using words like mitigate—which I supplied some alternative language that is more accessible. So the request was not to change the questions to statements. The current format is wordy and does not present as well as it did in the question format, which was more visually appealing. 
 
Also, this format now has markers of comments on it, can you remove them? I have one example below – I see them on other slides as well. Also there is a slide listed as a poll, when we have no planned polls for the session – can you remove that?

Subject:
 RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah

Boston Scientific does not have access to dropbox. Sarah should be able to add it to our SP. I’d like to see these changes made before presenting this to the Alpharetta leadership team:
Slide 4 has extra spaces in the sentence about using laptop for notes – before laptop, at the beginning of the sentence and after laptop
Missing a comma after, learn – for listen to learn, not judge
Slide 8 refers to Latinx – we need to consistently use Hispanic/Latino across the presentation
Slide 11 – for the purposes of the audience and to use more straightforward and plain language, further simplifying the first bullet point to “Recognize that it is best practice for work-related interactions to be conducted in English”

Slide 16 has an extra space in the first statement between colleagues and may.
Need to have periods after all the sentences for consistency.

 to your question in the separate chain – we will share information on timing of the sessions once the deck is approved and signed off after review with the Alpharetta leadership team.

subject: FW: {External} Regionalization update
body:
This is the email I sent her, it crossed with the email she sent me – sorry, I should have included you.
 
From:
 Sarah Nodarse 
Sent:
 Tuesday, June 4, 2024 10:15 AM
To:
 Chan, Bethany (she/her/hers) <Bethany.Chan@bsci.com>
Cc:
 Bird, Shani (she/her/hers) <Shani.Bird@bsci.com>
Subject:
 RE: {External} Regionalization update
 
Good morning Bethany,
 
As per our conversation during last week’s meeting, can we rethink our plan to review the regionalized versions during our bi-weekly meeting on the 12
th
? 
 
Since we are not going to be pushing to have the pilots in late June, but rather waiting until August, it would be beneficial to have a bit more time. I am working with our partners, and expecting material from them end of next week. Ideally, I could have a few days to review their contributions and do the formatting and integration before we review together. Would that be okay? We could either schedule a special session on June 18- you can pick the time as my day is fairly open (the 19
th
 is a holiday and I am off the 20
th
 and 21
st
) or wait until our next scheduled meeting on the 26
th
, extending that meeting to an hour. I am confident that the materials will be excellent and that we can sign off on them by early July so that the pilots can be planned anytime after mid-July.
 
We could use our meeting on the 12
th
 to review the eLearning, which is coming along nicely. I had my 1:1 with Camille today and we spoke about the video script, I told her she could contact me directly if she needs help with it.
 
Let me know your thoughts – thank you!
Sarah
 
 
 
From:
 Chan, Bethany (she/her/hers) <
Bethany.Chan@bsci.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, May 24, 2024 11:23 AM
To:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Bird, Shani (she/her/hers) <
Shani.Bird@bsci.com
>
Subject:
 RE: {External} Regionalization update
 
Hi Sarah,
 
What a great lineup! Thank you for the update. I like the idea of adding time to the June 12
th
 to allow time to go deeper into that. Can you add Shani to that meeting invite if she isn’t already on it when you update the length? It would be wonderful to have her perspective and introduction as well if she’s available. Let me know what timing would work best for Brian for a separate timing as well. I’m happy to meet later in the day or as early as 7 am if needed.
 
For the eLearning - I’m reviewing the script you sent as well and working on arranging studio time for Camille. Will keep you posted on that.
 
Hope you have a wonderful long weekend ahead!
 
Bethany
 
Bethany Chan, Ph.D.
Principal DE&I L&D Specialist
Enterprise Talent Management
Pronouns: (she/her/hers)
bethany.chan@bsci.com
4100 Hamline Ave N
Arden Hills, MN
www.bostonscientific.com
   
   
 
 
From:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, May 24, 2024 11:04 AM
To:
 Chan, Bethany (she/her/hers) <
Bethany.Chan@bsci.com
>
Subject:
 {External} Regionalization update
 
 
CAUTION
: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe. Be Security Conscious! 
 
Hi Bethany – before I sign off for the holiday weekend I wanted to let you know what progress we’ve made on the regionalization. We been busy securing the local talent who will help us and are very happy with the lineup: 
For APAC: Brian Schroeder, who is a longtime LCW associate who lives in Hong Kong. He has already delivered facilitation for BSC and is familiar with Leading Inclusively. 
LATAM: Adriana Medina, another longtime LCW associate who is Mexican, a Ph.D. interculturalist and experienced trainer
CANADA: Latoya Ming, a fantastic intercultural and management consultant who lives in Toronto and who is working with LCW on several projects at the moment (she is also going to be my co-facilitator for the Maple Grove workshop)
 
We are still working on AUS-NZ. I am meeting with each of the three listed above on Tuesday, they have already been briefed on the assignment. The next step would be for you to meet them (perhaps Adriana and Latoya could come to the Wednesday 5-29 meeting? We might need a separate time for Brian due to time zone) and for them to produce the slides quickly. I am going to aim to have the regionalized  versions ready for us to review at our bi-weekly meeting on June 12. We could even extend this meeting if you would like. That way, we still have the opportunity to schedule pilots before the July 4 holiday.
 
Let me know how that sounds! 
 
Talk to you next week,
Sarah
 
Sarah Nodarse
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW
4753 N Broadway, Flr. 2
Chicago, IL 60640
 
773-828-6781 (office)
773-474-9138 (direct)
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
 
Website | Twitter | Facebook | LinkedIn
View our upcoming events | Sign-up for our newsletter
 
I live and work in Chicago, IL – on the unceded territory of the Pokagon band of Potawatomi. See 
this article
 in the Chicago History Museum Magazine for a native perspective on land acknowledgements and the City of Chicago.

subject: FW: ARCH - Regional Customizations
body:

From:

Sent:

To:

Cc:
 Bird, Shani (she/her/hers) <Shani.Bird@bsci.com>
Subject:
 RE: ARCH - Regional Customizations
 
Hi – I just sent you an email, I had understood that we were aiming to review by June 25, to pilot APAC and LATAM, and possibly Canada in August. That is what I noted during our meeting on 5-29. I had also noted that we had a tentative plan to review at next week’s meeting on the 12th, but I had concerns about having the materials ready by then, and preferred the 18
th
 or 16
th
.
 
I am so sorry if I misunderstood something - ? Please do let me know.

subject: RE: {External} Formatted deck & confirmation of Alpharetta Spotlights Scheduling
body:
Good morning Hollina and team,
Please see updated PDF attached, with notes below. 
 
Slide 4 – spaces have been removed, did another review looking for rogue formatting issues
Throughout – periods after bulleted sentences are only if the sentence is a complete sentence, otherwise no period, I reviewed the entire document to apply this rule
Latinx has been changed to Hispanic/Latino on slide 8 and I did another check throughout the document
Slide 11 has been updated as per your instruction
 
Regarding slide 13, the one we have there is the slide we prefer to use, of the various versions we considered – we like this simple wording the best for explaining the concepts. It is indeed an interactive slide, here is the activity description from the speaker notes:
4 mins
TPOTS: To remind the group of the core skill that we are teaching – cultural competence
Say: Through the Race Matters and this H/L Spotlight, we are hoping to deepen your understanding of the different cultural communities present here at Alpharetta, and to provide you with tools for building your skill in shifting perspective and adapting behavior in order to contribute to the culture of inclusion on site.
Common thread for all sessions – learning these three things to do to develop cultural competence
Ask participants to REFLECT on ONE of the statements they see here and share their experience / reflections:
-Do these stages of cultural competence make sense?
-Can you see yourself doing these things?
-What seems easy?
-What seems difficult?
 
Let us know if you are ready to review this with Alpharetta leadership, so that we can move on to translations. 
 
Thank you for your partnership!
 
Sarah
 
 
Sarah Nodarse
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW
4753 N Broadway, Flr. 2
Chicago, IL 60640
 
773-828-6781 (office)
773-474-9138 (direct)
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
 
Website | Twitter | Facebook | LinkedIn
View our upcoming events | Sign-up for our newsletter
 
I live and work in Chicago, IL – on the unceded territory of the Pokagon band of Potawatomi. See 
this article
 in the Chicago History Museum Magazine for a native perspective on land acknowledgements and the City of Chicago.

Work in Progress,
 a Dropbox Conference 
October 15, 2024 
The Conservatory at One Sansome, San Francisco, CA 
From the personal computer, to the internet, to the smart phone—as technology evolves, so does the way we work, and AI is only accelerating the pace of change. Groundbreaking innovations are now around every corner. 
Join us for the Dropbox Work in Progress conference in October to dive deeper into the challenges and opportunities that come with this shift. It’s going to be an exciting, inspiring day, and you’ll leave with some practical tips for how to use AI (and Dropbox) to get even more out of your business. (Plus some awesome swag.)
